loans.name: Ilaz

texts.en: Ilaz wants to thank all of the lenders for the loan which helped him to renovate his house, including replacing the roof and doors and windows to improve the living conditions for his family. By having done this he will be able to avoid the extreme cold weather coming up soon during the winter. He is still working with his son transporting goods for other people and was very happy with the first loan; therefore, he is requesting a loan for the second time. This time, since he has built a balcony, he still needs to cover it with a roof and is requesting a 1500 euro loan for the new roof. By doing this he will have comfort in his house and a completed home. He wants to thanks all of the lenders for the second loan.

loans.use: To pay for the new roof for his balcony

loans.name: Naason

texts.en:
Naason is 53 years old. He would like to use this Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: María Teresa

texts.es:
La Señorita María forma parte del banco comunal Victoria del Portete. Vive por los alrededores de la parroquia La Victoria del Portete en Cuenca, lugar que tiene un clima frió, tiene amplias llanuras, verdes campos y una mezcla de la arquitectura moderna y antigua, su gente es a amable, gentil y de un corazón cálido, aun mantienen la cultura y tradiciones de sus pueblos.
La señorita María tiene 22 años de edad, es soltera y vive con su mamá quien se dedica a la ganadería, su padre no vive en el país. No tiene casa propia por lo que vive arrendando. E
Doña María es una mujer luchadora y emprendedora quien esta labrando su futuro con su trabajo, se dedica a laborar en una fábrica en donde se elabora calzado y en su casa se dedica a la crianza de animales, estas actividades le dan la facilidad ser independiente y a su vez muy responsable y ayudar en la economía de su familia. 
El dinero de su crédito anterior ha sido invertido en la compra de ganado al igual que su nuevo crédito también va a invertir para el incremento de ganado y así crecer más en este negocio. Su grupo de crédito le gusta por la solidaridad, compañerismo y amistad que hay entre todas las integrantes y amigas del grupo.
texts.en:
María is part of the Victoria del Portete communal bank.  She lives in the outskirts of the La Victoria del Portete parish in Cuenca.  This place has a cold climate, vast plains, green fields, and a mix of modern and ancient architecture.  Its people are kind, gentle, and have warm hearts.  They still maintain the cultures and traditions of their villages.

María is 22 years old and single.  She lives with her mother, who works with livestock.  Her father does not live in the country.  She does not have her own house, so she rents where she lives.

María is a tenacious and entrepreneurial woman who is carving out her future with her work.  She works in a factory where they make shoes.  At home she raises animals.  These business activities make it easier for her to be independent. In turn, she is very responsible and helps with the family finances.

The money from the previous loan was used to buy livestock.  This is the same as her new loan, which she will also use to increase her livestock.  This way she will grow more in this business.  She likes her communal bank because of the solidarity, camaraderie, and friendships that exist among the members and friends in the group.

loans.use: to buy livestock.

loans.name: Tupendane C Group

texts.en:
Emanuel, who is in his mid-30's, is a married father of two young children.  He has been selling a variety of foods and drinks such as sodas, juice, water, chips, fried chicken, miskaki and eggs for 10 years now. He has a second similar shop run by an employee, although Emanuel still monitors and supervises the shop. Working from 10:00 am until after midnight, he is able to make a very good profit per month.
 
This will be Emanuel's 10th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used his previous loans, all since repaid, to purchase a motorcycle, a fridge, and inventory for his businesses.  He used his profits to buy a radio, a sofa set, and a plot of land, and has built a small house at his village place.  He will use this loan to buy more drinks including sodas, juice and water to resell. Emanuel dreams of owning a wholesale shop and is so happy with the loans which have allowed him to improve his life.

Emanuel will share this loan with his loan group "Tupendane C," which has nine members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more drinks including sodas, juice and water to resell.

loans.name: Sleiman

texts.en:
Sleiman is a 30-year-old Lebanese married man. He is the main income source for his family, which is composed of his wife and only child. 

Ten years ago he acquired a van with which he used to run a transportation business driving students. He cooperates financially with his wife who works at a local school to live in good conditions. With his youth loan requested from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l, Sleiman will repair his van to secure and ease his transportation business. This is his first Kiva loan, and he hopes to be able to improve his business as well as the family’s financial situation.

loans.use: to repair his van

loans.name: Milton Jeovanni

texts.es:
Milton, invertirá de nuevo en su negocio y comprara camisas, blusas, gorras, y otros productos que le permitan tener un inventario muy diversificado para mantener a sus clientes actuales y atraer nuevos clientes, 
Con el crédito anterior su inventario aumento, sus ventas fueron mayores, las necesidades de los clientes fueron satisfechas, sus ingresos le permitieron cancelar la deuda y dar más apoyo económico en su casa.
texts.en:
Milton, will invest once again in his business, buying shirts, blouses, hats, and other products. This will allow him to maintain a diversified inventory to keep his current customers and to attract new ones. 

With the previous loan he increased his inventory, sales were higher, and his customers' needs were satisfied. His earnings allowed him to repay the loan and provide his home with more financial support.

loans.use: to buy shirts, blouses, hats, and other items.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Meet 46-year-old Mariama from Jui, located in the eastern area of Freetown. A married mother of four, Mariama established her fast food business in 2006, and works from 8:00 am until 7:00 pm seven days per week. She is very hardworking and desires to improve her standard of living.

Mariama requires a loan to purchase cassava, palm oil and seasonings in order to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income arising from this loan will allow her to feed her children and increase her business. In the future, Mariama plans to further expand her enterprise. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase cassava, palm oil and seasonings to expand her business.

loans.name: Jaime Samuel

texts.es: Samuel es un joven emprendedor de 19 años, soltero, vive con su madre quien trabaja como costurera. Viven en la ciudad de Santo Domingo de los Tsachilas, ubicada en la región costa, una ciudad muy productiva, su gente es muy dedicada al comercio ya que es la ciudad de conexión entre la sierra y la costa del Ecuador y es muy visitada. Samuel  terminó la secundaria gracias al apoyo de sus padres y uno de sus sueños es estudiar medicina, pero por no contar con el dinero decidió postergar sus estudios. Este hombre valiente y emprendedor se ha dedicado a hacer trabajos de albañilería para poder solventar sus necesidades y ayudar a su madre en los gastos del hogar. Sin embargo, él pensó en que debe esforzarse más para el cumplimiento de su sueño, es así como visitó las oficinas de Fundación Alternativa porque una clienta le dio muy buenas referencias y  se enteró que la institución ayuda a jóvenes emprendedores. Samuel requiere su crédito para poder comprar 40 quintales de arroz y emprender con su pequeña bodega de víveres, actividad que aprendió de su madre que en días de su juventud se dedicaba a la comercialización de víveres por lo que Samuel incluso ya cuenta con clientes  a quien además visitará todas las tardes brindándoles servicio a domicilio y algunas mañanas él continuará trabajando como maestro en construcción. Se siente muy feliz ya que con sus ingresos del negocio va a poder ahorrar para seguir con sus estudios y poder ser un profesional de excelencia para servir a su comunidad y salvar vidas. Samuel agradece a Fundación Alternativa quienes a través del portal de Kiva podrán financiar su emprendimiento depositando la confianza que él necesita para salir adelante.
texts.en:
Samuel is a young, 19-year old entrepreneur.  He is single and lives with his mother, who works as a seamstress.  They live in the city of Santo Domingo de los Tsachilas, situated in the coastal region.  It is a very productive city, and its people are very dedicated to commerce, since it is the city that connects the mountains to the Ecuadoran coast and is well visited.

Samuel finished high school thanks to his parents' support, and one of his dreams is to study medicine.  However, due to a lack of funds, he decided to postpone his studies.

This brave and entrepreneurial man has made his living doing construction work in order to cover his expenses and help his mother with household expenses.  Nevertheless, he felt that he should work harder in order to achieve his dream.  That was how he came to visit the offices of Fundación Alternativa, because a client gave him very good references and he found out that the institution helps young entrepreneurs.

Samuel needs this loan to be able to buy 40 quintals of rice and launch his small convenience store.  He learned this business from his mother, who in her younger days used to sell convenience store items, so Samuel already has customers whom he will visit in the afternoons providing them with delivery service.  Some mornings, he will continue to work as a construction worker.

He is very happy because with his earnings from the business, he will be able to save in order to continue his studies and be an excellent professional who serves his community and saves lives.

Samuel is grateful to Fundación Alternativa who, through Kiva, will be able to finance his undertaking, putting in him the faith that he needs to get ahead.

loans.use: to buy 40 quintals of rice and to start his convenience store.

loans.name: Mawen

texts.en:
Mawen is 32 years old and lives in the Paynesville South Area of Liberia. It is a suburb of the capital city of Monrovia and one of the most populated areas in Montserrado County. The area boasts one of the best standards of living in the county with affordable rents, good roads, access to water and lots of transportation options. Mawen is married and has four children aged between 8 and 16 who live at home and are currently attending school. 

For the past ten years she has been cooking and selling rice and soup in the local market. She started this business with money given to her by her husband, and she enjoys her business because it gives her more money. She sells six days a week, from 7 am to 5 pm, and most of the time she uses a taxi to get her goods to her shop.
 
She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, fish, pepper, onion, meat, etc. for her business. Her plans are to build a house and educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, fish, pepper, onion, meat, etc. for her business

loans.name: Nathanael

texts.en:
Nathanael is 54 years old. He is married with four children. He would like to use this Kiva loan to support labor costs and to buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Pierre

texts.en:
Pierre is 49 years old. He is married with five children. He has been in the business for the past 19 years. He would like to use this Kiva loan to support labor costs and to buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa is 34 years old and married with five children between the ages of 1 and 17 years. She resides in Jui Eastern area in Freetown.

She's been in business nine years, selling fish in her community.  She says her main business problem is sometimes slow purchasing power.

Hawa requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy fish for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and educate her children. In the future, she would like to expand her business more than ever. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy fish for resale.

loans.name: Jean Pierre

texts.en:
Jean Pierre is age 33. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. He wishes to invest profits from his farming in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Nicodem

texts.en:
Nicodem is 45 years old, married to a farmer, and has four children. He is requesting a loan, which he will use  to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production.  He needs fertilizer in order to increase production. With the profits from his farming, he hopes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to purhcase fertilizers and support labor costs

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en:
Ramatu is 35 years old and married. She has three children between the ages of two and fifteen years. She runs a domestic product business in Jui, in the eastern area of Freetown.

Rmatu has been in this business for nine years, and also sells fish within her community. She says that the main problem to her business sometimes is slow purchasing power.

Ramatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy fish for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and educate her children. In the future, she would like to expand her business more than ever. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy fish for resale.

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Meet 28-year-old Zainab from Jui eastern area in Freetown. She is a single mother of one child.  For the past 10 years, Zainab has operated a clothing business. She began her business because she wanted to create a source of income. She works at the business from 8:00 a.m. until 7:00 p.m., seven days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is a lack of capital to expand her business.

Zainab requires a loan in order to purchase more trousers and blouses to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to change her status of living and increase her business. In the future, Zainab plans to expand her business more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more trousers and blouses to expand her business.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Meet 27-year-old Emma from Jui eastern area in Freetown. She is a single mother of one child.  In 2010, Emma established a fried chicken business. She began her business because she wanted to create a source of income. She works at the business from 8:00 a.m. until 7:00 p.m., seven days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is a lack of capital to expand her business.

Emma requires a loan to purchase more cartons of chicken and cooking oil to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to change her status of living and increase her business. In the future, Emma plans to expand her business more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more cartons of chicken and cooking oil to expand her business.

loans.name: Jose Martir

texts.es:
José, es casado, vive con su esposa y sus cuatro hijos, los cuales dependen por completo de él. Su actividad económica es la reparación de zapatos, es un oficio que  aprendió desde que tenía ocho años y tiene gran demanda en la zona donde reside. Por su experiencia no tiene ningún problema en atenderlo.
 Necesita comprar plantillas, pegas, hilo, agujas, tenazas y otros, para la reparación de zapatos, así tendrá un inventario que le permitirá entregar sus trabajos a tiempo y satisfacer a sus clientes.
José sueña con generar ingresos que le permitan tener un chalet de reparación de zapatos, pagar la deuda que adquirió y ahorrar para darles una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
José is married and lives with his wife and four children, who are completely dependent on him.  His business involves repairing shoes.  He learned this trade when he was eight years old and there is a great demand for this service in the area where he lives.  Throughout his experience, he has never had any problems with managing his business.  

José needs stencils, glue, thread, needles, pliers, and other supplies that he needs for repairing shoes.  As a result, he will have the inventory that will allow him to perform his work on time and to the satisfaction of his customers.  

José dreams of generating enough income to have his own shoe repair shop, to pay off the debt he acquired, and to save toward providing a good education for his children.

loans.use: to buy stencils, glue, thread, needles, pliers, and other supplies.

loans.name: Vesta

texts.en:
Vesta is 67 years old. She would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. She wishes to invest the profits from her farming in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Deus

texts.en: Deus, 50, is a resident of a rural area in the Kabingo Isingiro district. He has been in farming since childhood. Because of his hard work, he has managed to put up very big banana plantations. This business has helped him to sustain his family and to support education of his relatives. He is requesting a loan of UGX 1,500,000 to help him buy manure for his new plantation which he is trying to establish.

loans.use: To buy manure

loans.name: Adama

texts.en:
Meet Adama. She is 25 years old and from Jui, an eastern area in Freetown. She is married, with two children.  

In 2008, Adama established her fertilizer business. She began her business because she wanted to generate a permanent source of income. She works at the business every day, nine hours per day. She says that the main challenge to her business is that she walks a long distance to meet her customers.

Adama requires a loan in order to purchase more fertilizer, to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to change her standard of living and increase her business. 

In the future, Adama plans to open a big fertilizer shop. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more fertilizer, to expand her business.

loans.name: Jean Nepomuscene

texts.en:
Jean Nepomuscene is 36 years old. He has four children and his wife works as a farmer. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production; he needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Zatoon

texts.en:
Zatoon is a 40-year-old married woman who has enjoyed the work of making parandas for so many years.  Parandas are considered a traditional hair accessory in countries like Pakistan.  Women use it for a traditional look on special occasions, like weddings and Eid (a holiday).  Zatoon makes beautiful parandas, especially for bridal hairstyles.  She initiated her business with the support of Kashf Foundation.  Taking a loan from Kashf helped her to account for expenses she thought she could never bear.  She is striving hard to meet her family expenditures.  She is responsible for providing her family a good environment, with good food, clothing, and education. 

Zatoon needs a loan of PKR 25,000 to buy raw material for embellishment (colorful threads, beads, mirrors, and pearls).  It would increase her sales and profits.  She is in her 2nd loan cycle with a good repayment history.

loans.use: to buy raw material including colorful threads, beads, mirrors, and pearls.

loans.name: Gbolu

texts.en:
45-year-old Gbolu operates a shop selling soft drink in the Paynesville South Area of Liberia. It is a suburb of the capital city of Monrovia and one of the most populated areas in Montserrado County. The area boasts one of the best standards of living in the county with affordable rents, good roads, access to water and lots of transportation options. 
She is married and has three children aged between 15 and 30, only one is currently attending school and lives at home. Gbolu completed grade 11 before starting her business. She describes herself as a good business woman.
Gbolu has had this shop for the past eight years now. She works eight hours, six days a week at her business.  Her greatest challenge in business is the rainy season. She intends to use the loan to buy more soft drink. She started her business by help from her husband.  She likes her business because she has more customers.  In the future, she wants to own a house.  
She wants to thank the lenders for supporting BRAC Liberia and its borrowers.

loans.use: to buy more soft drink.

loans.name: Sallay

texts.en:
Meet Sallay: she is in her late thirties and is from Jui, the eastern area in Freetown. She is married with 3 children. In 2005, Sallay established her ground nut business. She began her business because she wanted to generate a permanent source of income. She works at the business from 8:00am until 7:00pm, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is insufficient capital to expand her business.

Sallay requires a loan in order to purchase more bags of ground nuts to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to change her status of living and increase her business. In the future, Sallay plans to expand her business more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more bags of ground nuts to expand her business.

loans.name: Rugiatu

texts.en:
Meet 38-year-old Rugiatu, from Jui, an eastern area in Freetown. She is married, with six children.  

For the past 18 years, Rugiatu has operated a bread business. She began her business because she did not have money to empower herself. She works at the business from 8:00am until 7:00pm, seven days per week. She is very hard-working and desires to improve her standard of living.

Rugiatu requires a loan in order to purchase more flour and sugar, to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to feed her children and increase her business. 

In the future, Rugiatu plans to further expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more flour and sugar, to expand her business.

loans.name: Kulah

texts.en:
Please meet 35-year-old Kulah, from Paynesville South, in Liberia. Paynesville South is a suburb of the capital city of Monrovia. It is the area in Montserrado County with the highest population and the best standards of living. There are good roads, access to water, affordable rents, and many transportation options in the area. 

Kulah is single and she has three children, six, 12, and 19 years old. All three of her children go to school and live with her at home.  She describes herself as a serious woman.

Kulah owns her own cook shop (restaurant) business, which she has been running for the past five years. She began doing her business with money from her husband. In her business, she faces transportation issues.  Her favorite part of her business is the profit she makes, every time, from her business.  One day, she hopes to own a house.  

Kulah intends to use the loan to buy more food ingredients, such as fish, pepper, vita, oil, and onions. She is grateful for your support!

loans.use: to buy more food ingredients, such as fish, pepper, vita, oil, and onions.

loans.name: Janvier

texts.en:
Janvier is 49 years old. He would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. He wishes to invest the profits from his farming in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Meet 35-year-old Hawa from Jui eastern area in Freetown. She is married and has two children. In 2006, Hawa established her retail business. She began her business because she wants to create income to support her children. She works at the business from 8 am until 7 pm, seven days per week. Her major hardship is low income.

Hawa requires a loan in order to purchase rice, palm oil and cooking seasoning to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to feed her children and increase her business. In the future, Hawa plans to expand her business further. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase rice, palm oil and cooking seasoning to expand her business.

loans.name: Pastor

texts.es: Don Pastor, tiene 50 años de edad, vive en unión libre con su esposa con quien tiene tres hijos y reside en el municipio de Macuelizo, Santa Bárbara. El siempre se ha dedicado a la agricultura y hace 2 años que decidió con su esposa poner una pulpería para obtener un poco mas de ingresos. Vende productos de la canasta básica como refrescos, manteca, harina, arroz, azúcar, maíz, frijoles,  pollo, embutidos, lácteos, churros etc.El préstamo que solicita es por  10,000 Lempiras y lo va invertir en la compra de productos como arroz, maíz, frijoles, lácteos, refrescos, azúcar, pan, café etc. para la venta.  Su meta es crecer más con su negocio  y ayudar a sus hijos en los estudios para que puedan salir adelante.
texts.en:
Don Pastor is 50 years old and in a common-law relationship with his wife.  They have three children and reside in the town of Macuelizo, Santa Bárbara.  

Pastor has always been a farmer, but two years ago, he and his wife decided to open a grocery store in order to earn a little more income.  He sells basic household products such as soft drinks, lard, flour, rice, sugar, corn, beans, chicken, cured meats, dairy products, snack foods, and other items.  The loan he is requesting is in the amount of 10,000 HNL and will be invested in the purchase of products such as rice, corn, beans, dairy products, soft drinks, sugar, bread, coffee, and other items that he can sell.  His goal is to grow his business and to help his children with their studies so that they can get ahead.

loans.use: to buy rice, corn, beans, dairy products, soft drinks, sugar, bread, coffee, and other items.

loans.name: Elevanie

texts.en:
Elevanie is 57 years old. She has been a farmer for the past eight years. She would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. She wishes to invest the profits from her farming in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Elias

texts.es:
Elías, comprara terneros para criarlos y luego venderlos, le ayudará a fortalecer su negocio para tener mejores ganancias, Elías sabe que administrando bien sus actividades económicas obtiene mejores resultados, en el crédito anterior tuvo beneficios como mayor productividad e ingresos que respaldan la responsabilidad en el pago de sus deudas.
Sigue trabajando para ampliar el negocio, estabilizarse económicamente, seguir satisfaciendo los pedidos de sus clientes y dentro de todos los esfuerzos su prioridad es dar a su familia mejor alimentación y salud.
texts.en: Elías will buy calves to rear and sell, which will allow him to strengthen his business and increase his earnings. Elías knows that managing his economic activities well will give him better results. With his previous loan he saw benefits such as greater productivity and income, which supported him in making his repayments. He will keep on working to expand his business, find economic stability and continue fulfilling his customers' orders. At the heart of all of his endeavours is the wish to give his family better food and health.

loans.use: to buy calves to rear.

loans.name: Sama

texts.en: Sama is 27 years old and lives in Montserrado County, which has the largest free-port and is the number one commercial county in Liberia. She is single with two children, ages 3 and 7, who are in school and live at home. She did not go to school, but she manages her business well. For the past two years she has been selling rice and oil in the local market. She started this business with money given to her by her boyfriend. She enjoys her business because the business gives her more money. She sells six days a week, from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m., and most of the time she uses the bus to get her goods to her table. She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice and oil for her business. Her plans are to build a house and own a shop.

loans.use: to purchase more rice and oil for her business

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Meet 28-year-old Sarah from Jui eastern area in Freetown. She is married with one child. In 2006, Sarah established a cake business. She began her business because she wants to be responsible for her children. She works at the business from 8:00 a.m. until 7:00 p.m., seven days per week. She is very hardworking and desires to improve her standard of living.

Sarah requires a loan in order to purchase flour, sugar, and cooking oil to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to repay her loan and increase her business. In the future, Sarah plans to expand her business more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase flour, sugar, and cooking oil to expand her business.

loans.name: Laurence

texts.en:
Laurence is 38 years old. She is married and has spent 12 years in farming. She would like to use her Kiva loan to pay for labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase her production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future, she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 


The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs

loans.name: Esperanza Asegurada Group

texts.en:
Carmela is one of our businesswomen. She sells grocery products in her small store in her house. This kind of business is called a "Colmado". She is a mother with two children. Only one of them lives with her and her long-term partner. They both work to support the needs of their household, and Carmela works every day to provide her children with a good education, clothing and food.

She belongs to the "Esperanza Asegurada" Group together with 15 neighbors who also work hard to bring more stability to their families. Carmela is receiving her 11th loan from Esperanza Internacional and, because her loan repayments have been made punctually, she has been able to strengthen her business and make good investments. Her plan for this new loan is to invest in her business by buying different types of goods for daily meals, to increase her business inventory and to give better service to her clients. She uses the profits from the sales she makes to save and reinvest in her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy rice, beans, sugar, flour, canned foods, and others goods

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 35 years old, married, and has three children between the age of 5 and 13 years. She runs a domestic product business in Jui, an eastern area in Freetown.

She's been in this business since 2009, and sells glass cups, knives and food containers to customers within her community. She says that the main problem for her business is sometimes there is slow purchasing power.

Fatmata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more spoons and varieties of food container for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to increase her business and take care of her family. In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more spoons and varieties of food container for resale.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en: Marie is 44 years old and lives in Montserrado County, which has the largest free-port and is the number one commercial county in Liberia. She is married with four children between the ages of 18 to 23 who attend school and live at home. She has been selling door locks, hinges, nails, etc., for the past seven years now. She started this business with money given to her by her husband and she learns this business from her husband. Her favorite part about her business is that it gives her more profit. She is requesting a loan to purchase more door locks, hinges, nails, etc., for her business. In the future, she wants to build a house for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more door locks, hinges, nails, etc., for her business

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en:
Aminata is 38 years old, married, and has four children. She is from Jui in the eastern area of Freetown. In 2006, Aminata established a retail food business. She works from 8:00 AM until 7:00 PM, seven days a week. 

Aminata is requesting a loan, which she will use to purchase rice, palm oil, and cooking seasonings to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to feed her children, improve her standard of living, and increase her business. In the future, Aminata plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase rice, palm oil, and cooking seasonings

loans.name: Yawa

texts.en: Yawa is 40 years old and lives in Montserrado County, which has the largest port and is the number one commercial county in Liberia. She is married and has five children between the ages of 2 and 22. They are in school and live at home. She has been selling hinges, nails, door locks, etc. for the past four years. She started this business by working with her sister, and she learned the business from her friends. Her favorite part about her business is that it gives her more profit. She is requesting a loan to purchase more hinges, nails, door locks, etc. for her business. In the future she wants to build a house for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more hinges, nails, door locks, etc. for her business

He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

loans.name: Diego

texts.en: Diego is a Guatemalan artisan who specializes in hand-carved wood art. He would like to invest in the purchase of wood sealer, a band saw and sustainable local woods like mahogany, cedar, granadillo, guachipilin and coffee. Diego has been selling through NOVICA since 2011. This is his story: "What I enjoy the most about my work is also my biggest challenge: creating new designs. Wood is a noble element, totally transformable, that gives you a lot if you know how to work it, treat it and take care of it. I remember with much gratefulness a companion in the first workshop where I worked. He took a lot of time to teach me things I never imagined possible to do with my hands. Now I spend some of my time teaching the young people who work with me." "May God bless you for offering me this microcredit; you are like angels! By being able to purchase what I need I'll be able to continue working along with my team, which means we'll be able to continue providing for our families. The fact that you are offering me your support is something I will always cherish in my heart." Use the link below to view Diego's hand-carved wood art on the NOVICA site: http://www.novica.com/kiva/8047

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of wood sealer, a band saw and sustainable local woods like mahogany, cedar, granadillo, guachipilin and coffee

loans.name: Tenneh

texts.en:
Tenneh, age 53, sells a variety of door locks in her community. She has been engaged in her business since 2010. Sometimes she has more customers than other times, but she generally makes a good profit. 

Tenneh and her fiancé live in Westpoint in Montserrado County, which has the largest free port and is the number one commercial county in Liberia. Her fiancé also runs his own business. They have raised four children, now between the ages of 23 and 30 years old. One of them attends school and two of them live at home. 

Tenneh is requesting a loan in order to purchase more door locks for her business. 

In the future, she plans to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase door locks to offer for sale

loans.name: Julia Bernardina

texts.es:
La   señora  Julia Bernardina de 48 años  es casada vive en su casa de habitación junto con sus hijos de edades entre veinte y dos y veinte y cinco años, vive  en  el municipio de Pespire al sur de Honduras.
Doña  Julia Bernardina se dedica desde hace 08 años a la elaboración y venta de pan como rosquillas, quesadillas, hojaldras,  tustacas y también elabora nacatamales de cerdo y nacatamales de pollo,  toda  esta actividad forman parte de sus ingresos, su negocio está ubicado en  el sur de Honduras y sus clientes son los vecinos y amigos de su colonia.
Doña  Julia Bernardina está solicitando el préstamo para compra de harina, leña, soda, azúcar, huevos, hojas para envolver los tamales etc. Con el apoyo de este préstamo desea que su negocio crezca  y tener el suficiente producto para vender en estos meses que las ventas son más altas
Doña  Julia Bernardina su sueño es  tener su propia panadería.

San Lorenzo, Honduras – Octubre del 2013
texts.en:
Señora Julia Bernardina is 48 years old. She is married and lives in her home with her children aged between 22 and 25 in the town of Pespire in the south of Honduras.

For the last 8 years Doña Julia has worked making and selling bread products such as doughnuts, quesadillas, hojaldras (a fried pastry) tustacas (corn cookies) and also nacatamales with pork or chicken. All of this is part of her income, and her business is located in the south of Honduras. Her customers are her friends and neighbors.

Doña Julia is asking for this loan in order to buy flour, firewood, soda, sugar, eggs, leaves to wrap her tamales, etc. With the support of this loan she wants to expand her business and have enough produce to sell in the months when sales are highest. Her dream is to have her own bakery.

San Lorenzo, Honduras – October 2013

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Fatumata

texts.en:
Fatumata is 24 years old. She lives in Congo town in Montserrado County, which is the largest in Freeport and is the number one commercial county in Liberia. Her fiancee is a local businessman and they have one child who attends school. For the past six years, Fatumata has been selling oil. She started this business with money from her fiancee. 

Fatumata is requesting a loan, which she will use to purchase more oil for her business. She plans to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase oil

loans.name: Alejandro

texts.en: Alejandro is a Peruvian artisan who specializes in Peru's traditional retablos (dioramas). He would like to invest in the purchase of raw materials such as plaster, ceramic, plywood and paint. Alejandro has been selling through NOVICA since 2002. This is his story: "I create retablos – colorful dioramas unique to the Ayacucho region of Peru. Each tiny figure is shaped and painted by hand, and displayed in a delightful tableau. In every one of my works you can find the labors of my wife, who molds the characters, as well as that of my nieces and nephews, whom I currently teach. The customs and traditions of the Andean people emerge in every retablo. Thank you all for supporting our crafts and promoting traditional arts through your microcredit. I'll be able to stock up on the materials I need to prepare for the holiday season." Use the link below to view Alejandro's traditional Andean retablos (dioramas) on the NOVICA site: http://www.novica.com/kiva/3210

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of raw materials such as plaster, ceramic, plywood and paint

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Meet 45-year-old Nancy from Jui eastern area in Freetown. She is married with four children. In 2006, Nancy established a retail business. She began her business because she did not go school and she was trained in business. She works at the business from 8:00 a.m. until 7:00 p.m., seven days per week. She is very hardworking and desires to improve her standard of living.

Nancy requires a loan in order to purchase rice, palm oil, and cooking seasoning to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to feed her children and increase her business. In the future, Nancy plans to expand her business more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase rice, palm oil, and cooking seasoning to expand her business.

loans.name: Nii Noi

texts.en: Nii Noi is a Ghanaian artisan who specializes in traditional hand-carved masks and sculptures. He would like to invest in the purchase of wood, potassium, calico and other fabrics to increase production. Nii Noi has been selling through NOVICA since 2000. This is his story: "I specialize in the carvings of antiquity. My collections are purely African, concentrating on West Africa and Central Africa, Congo in particular. These areas are heavily influenced by the spiritual power of objects, especially fetish items. I restore collected antiques, as well as create new carvings." "I am so grateful for your support. Please believe that by granting me this microcredit my business will grow significantly." Use the link below to view Nii Noi's traditional carvings on the NOVICA site: http://www.novica.com/kiva/1264

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of wood, potassium, calico and other fabrics to increase production

loans.name: Magno

texts.es:
Magno, es soltero y tiene un hijo que es independiente, vive en casa propia ocupando una habitación con paredes de ladrillo y el piso de tierra, la casa se encuentra ubicada en la zona de Pampahasi de la ciudad de La Paz.
Actualmente trabaja como chófer trayendo madera del Beni y de los yungas por mas de ocho o diez horas conduciendo y arriesgando su vida ya que a veces conduce toda la noche.
El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de madera ya que desea iniciar el negocio de la importación de madera hacia La Paz para mejorar sus ingresos y su calidad de vida ya que con lo poco que gana debe cubrir los gastos de alimentación y pago de servicios básicos.
El sueño de Magno es tener su propia empresa de importación y también hacer construir su casa para tener mas comodidad y seguridad
Es la primera vez que solicita crédito junto a IMPRO y la primera vez con KIVA.
texts.en:
Magno is single and has an adult son. He lives in his own home, with brick walls and a dirt floor. His home is located in Pampahasi, near La Paz. He currently works as a truck driver, transporting wood from Beni and the tropical valleys. He often drives for more than 8 or 10 hours and risks his life, since sometimes he drives through the night.

He will invest the loan in the purchase of wood because he wants to start his own business importing wood to La Paz. This will increase his income and quality of life, since he currently spends the little money that he earns on food and basic services. 

Magno's dream is to have his own importing business and he would also like to perform renovations on his home to make it more comfortable and secure. This is Magno's first loan with IMPRO and KIVA.

loans.use: to purchase wood to sell in La Paz to increase his income.

loans.name: Rugiatu

texts.en:
Meet Rugiatu: she is 28 years old from Jui eastern area in Freetown. She is married with 3 children. 

In 2005, Rugiatu established her palm oil business. She began her business because she wants to generate a permanent source of income. She works at the business from 8:00am until 7:00pm, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is insufficient capital to expand her business.

Rugiatu requires a loan in order to purchase more palm oil to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to change her status of living and increase her business. In the future, Rugiatu plans to open a restaurant. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil for resale.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.es:
Para la siembra de más chapola de café y mantenimiento del que ya existe cultivado
Doña Gladys tiene 53 años de edad es madre de cinco hijos los cuales viven bajo su techo y a ninguno le gusto estudiar ya que prefirieron a poyar a sus padres en las diferentes actividades del campo también con ella vive también un nieto. Ella es ama de casa y agricultora, casada con un grado de educación primaria incompleta cursado hasta el quinto grado. Como madre de familia, mujer emprendedora y trabajadora vela por el bienestar de su familia y decidió hace muchos años dedicarse a la caficultura ya que el trabajo es difícil y cansado pero las recompensas son muchas trabajando de manera correcta. También se dedica al comercio ya que hace 10 años implemento una pequeña pulpería la cual maneja en compañía de sus hijos dividiéndose el trabajo en ocasiones algunas veces en el campo y otras en el negocio de pulpería. La tierra que trabajan es propia la cual la adquirió su esposo mediante la compra a un cliente hace muchos años la cual está ubicada a 40 minutos de camino desde su casa de habitación.
Ella ha solicitado financiamiento a la cooperativa COMIXMUL para el cultivo de más café y distribuir una parte para la compra de insumos y poder abonar parte de la que ya existe mejorando la plantación y asegurando la cosecha al final de la temporada.
Actualmente su meta es proteger sus cultivos asistirlos de forma especial y fortalecerlos de manera que al final de la cosecha ella pueda sacar las ganancias esperadas y poder obtener ingresos para cumplir con su compromiso. Sus sueños son los de poder abrir carretera hasta sus cultivos facilitando el acceso para poder hacer que sus clientes fácilmente lleguen hasta el punto de ubicación para la venta del producto.
texts.en:
Doña Gladys is 53 years old and has 5 children and a grandchild who live with her. None of her children liked studying as they preferred to help their parents with the various agricultural activities.

She is a housewife and farmer, married with an education up to 5th grade. As a mother, entrepreneur and a hard-worker, she is responsible for her family's well-being and so she decided many years ago to start growing coffee. Although the work is hard and tiring, the rewards are many, working in the right way. Doña Gladys also works in business as 10 years ago she implemented a small grocery store which she runs with her children, on occasions sharing the work out, with some in the fields and others in the grocery business. The land they work is their own, and her husband acquired it through a customer many years ago. It is located 40 minutes from their home.

Doña Gladys is asking the COMIXMUL cooperative for the loan in order to grow more coffee, and also to use part of it for buying supplies and improving the plantation to ensure the harvest at the end of the season.

Currently her aim is to protect their crops, help them and strengthen them so that at the end of the harvest she can get the income she hopes for and be able to pay back the loan. Her dream is to build a road leading to their farmland, making access easier so that her customers can easily come and buy the produce where it is grown.

loans.use: to sow more coffee plants and maintain the existing crops.

loans.name: Teresa De Jesus

texts.es:
Teresa, tiene más demanda de sus productos y necesita comprar camarones frescos, moluscos, conchas y pescados, con esta inversión cumplirá con las necesidades de sus clientes, el crédito anterior le ayudo a diversificar los productos, sus ventas fueron mayores, gano nuevos clientes.
Su economía ha mejorado, sigue ampliando su negocio, ha cumplido con el pago de sus cuotas. Su familia tiene mejor educación, salud y una alimentación más adecuada.
texts.en:
Teresa has a higher demand for her products and needs to buy fresh prawns, molluscs, other shellfish and fish. With this investment she will meet the needs of her customers.

Teresa's previous loan helped her to diversify her products, her sales went up and she won new customers. Her finances have improved, and she continues to expand her business and she has made her repayments on time. Teresa's family now has a better education, health and a more adequate diet.

loans.use: to buy fresh prawns, molluscs, shellfish and fish.

loans.name: Mamie

texts.en: Mamie is 25 years old and lives in Montserrado County, which has the largest Freeport and is the number one commercial county in Liberia. She is single with a three-year-old child who is in school and lives at home. For the past three years she has been selling rubber dishes. She started this business with money that she borrowed from her mother. Her favorite part about her business is that she makes more profit. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bowls, cups, plates and spoons for her business. In the future she wants to build her house and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more bowls, cups, plates and spoons for her business

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en:
Meet 45-year-old Kadiatu from Jui, Eastern area in Freetown. She is married with 5 children.  

In 2006, Kadiatu established a retail business. She began her business because she did not go school but she was trained in business.  She works at the business from 8:00am until 7:00pm, 7 days per week. Her major business problem is insufficient capital to expand her business.

Kadiatu requires a loan in order to purchase rice, palm oil and cooking seasoning to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to feed her children and increase her business. 

In the future, Kadiatu plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase rice, palm oil and cooking seasoning to expand her business.

loans.name: Walter

texts.en:
Walter is a Peruvian artisan who specializes in replications of Inca sculptures. To increase production, he would like to invest in the purchase of a new kiln as well as in clay, pigments and paintbrushes. Walter has been selling through NOVICA since 2010. This is his story: "Our ancestors crafted beautiful and complex pieces with only their hands as tools, without the kind of technology we have nowadays. Through their work they expressed all that they saw and wondered about, their thoughts and beliefs. I feel that Peruvian ceramic art is a way to communicate with our ancestors and to keep them alive. Believe it or not, some archeologists have been fooled by my work! That's because of the aging process I use with my pieces. "Thank you for collaborating with us by way of this microcredit. Together we make it possible to continue developing our art and sharing it with the world." Use the link below to view Walter's ceramic Inca replicas on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/7284

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of a new kiln as well as in clay, pigments and paintbrushes

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Meet 40-year-old Fatmata from Jui, the eastern area of Freetown. She is married with four children, between the ages of 12 and 20. Fatmata has had her retail business for the past 10 years. She began her business because she wanted to create a source of income for herself. She works at her business from 8:00 am until 7:00 pm, seven days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is lack of capital to expand her business.
Fatmata requires a loan in order to purchase more cream, earrings, bracelets, and chains to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to change her status of living and increase her business. In the future, Fatmata plans to expand her business more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more cream, earrings, bracelets, and chains to expand her business.

loans.name: Felecia

texts.en:
Felecia is 34 years old and lives in Montserrado County, the home of the countries largest Freeport and number one commercial county in Liberia. She is single with 4 children between 3 and 10 years of age who are attending school and live at home.  

She has been selling bread, sugar, soap, etc. for the past 7 years. She says that her main business challenge is the transportation cost. She started this business with money given to her by her mother and she learned this business from her friends. Her favorite part about her business is that it gives her money; and what makes her proud is that it enables her to take care of her children and herself. 

She is requesting this loan to purchase more bread, sugar, soap, etc. to expand her sales.  She plans to build a house for her children in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more bread, sugar, soap, etc. to expand her sales.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Ghanaian artisan, Daniel, specializes in hand-carved items, including traditional masks and drums. He would like to invest in the purchase of wood, goatskin, polish, and sandpaper for production.

Daniel has been selling through NOVICA since 2007. This is his story:

"I'm married and I have four children, but I also look after five other children. I had already worked in carpentry when my brother-in-law, Samuel, taught me the art of carving. I specialize in traditional masks and African drums, and I usually get a good response from people. However, due to financial constraints, I'm not able to produce more work to meet the demand. I love to create new designs, so I constantly work to diversify my collection. I have taught more than ten people how to carve, and they are now also well-established in this trade."

"I thank all the people who are supporting me to increase my business through this microcredit. It will also make it possible for me to pay my children's school fees."

Use the link below to view Daniel's hand-carved masks and drums on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/6552

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of wood, goatskin, polish, and sandpaper for production.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a 20-year-old single young man from Deir Al-Balah. He lives with his family in a very simple house in the city. His father, who provides the sole income for the family, works as a public sector employee for a low income. Mohammad is a student at a local collage where he studies Information Technology. He dreams to earn a BA degree and help his family with part of their expenses. 

Mohammad took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a new laptop for his studies. By taking this loan, Mohammad will be able to write his homework and reports easily. 

Mohammad appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a new laptop for his studies

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 46 years old. He would like to use Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future, he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and supports labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Sumah

texts.en: This is Sumah from Liberia. She is 39 years old and lives in West Point, one of the most populated and well known markets in Montserrado county. Presently she is selling cold water and soft drinks in the local market, which she is managing in order to make some money. She sells for six days a week, spending 10 hours per day. She lives with three children out of five and only the three with her are currently attending school. For the past three years she has been doing this business. She explains that sometimes buying goes slow, but most of the time she realizes a profit and she uses it to sustain her family. She is requesting a loan to purchase more cold water and soft drinks for her business. She wishes in the near future to build a decent house. She appreciates the supporters of BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase more cold water and soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Oasis Group

texts.en:
Tomasina is one of our businesswomen. She works selling grocery products in her small store in her house. This kind of business is called "Colmado". She is a mother with 3 children and they live together with her. She is a single mom. Tomasina works every day to provide her children with a good education, clothing and food. 

She belongs to the "Oasis" Group together with 15 other micro-entrepreneurs who also work hard to bring more stability to their families. Tomasina is receiving her second loan from Esperanza Internacional, because her loan repayments have been made punctually. 

Her plan for this new loan is to invest in her business by buying different types of goods for daily meals, to increase her business inventory and to give better service to her clients. She uses the profits from the sales she makes to provide for her family. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy rice, flour, beans, meat, canned food, etc.

loans.name: Juan Jose

texts.es: El señor Juan Jose, le dedica gran parte de su tiempo a la agricultura ya que  para el es su medio de sobrevivir, actualmente tiene 3 manzanas de Piña cosechada y requiere de capital para darle un optimo mantenimiento, el credito lo solicita para comprar. urea, triple, completo, fertilizante ya que dentro de un mes sacara parte de la cosecha y quiere que su fruto se de calidad para obtener mejores ganancias y asi seguir mejorando sus condiciones de vida junto a su familia
texts.en:
Juan Jose spends a large part of his time farming because it is his means of survival.  He currently has three ‘manzanas’  [Central American unit of land measurement] of pineapples.  He needs money in order to give them optimum maintenance.

He is requesting the loan to buy urea and a variety of fertilizers.  Within one month he will get part of the harvest, and he wants his fruit to be quality in order to get better income.  This way he will continue improving his living conditions together with his family.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Peruth

texts.en:
Peruth is 57 years old. She is married and has been a maize farmer for the past eight years. She would like to use Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future, she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and supports labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 46 years old and lives in Montserrado County, home of the country's largest Freeport and the number one commercial county in Liberia. She is married with four children between 3 and18 years of age who are in school and live at home. 

Rebecca has been operating a shop for the past ten years.  She started this business thorough the help of her husband and she learned this business from her mother. Her favorite part about her business is that every day she makes some money and she makes lots of profit. She is requesting this loan to purchase more goods (Oil) for her business. She appreciates the supporters of BRAC Liberia and she promises to payback her loan on time.

loans.use: to purchase more goods (Oil) for her business

loans.name: Alaa

texts.en:
Alaa is a 31-year-old married man from Rafah city. He lives with his wife and four kids, one boy and three girls, in a small house. 

Alaa is an employee in the public sector where he earns a low income; this is the only source of income for the family. Alaa would like to improve his family's  conditions by buying all of the necessary stuff. 

Alaa took a USD Murabaha loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a solar-powered water heating system for his home. By applying this loan, the family will reduce their electricity-use for heating water, especially in the winter. This will improve the family living conditions. 

Alaa appears in the photo

loans.use: to buy a solar-powered water heating system for his home

loans.name: Senan

texts.en:
Sanan is 36 years old and is a parquet master. He is married with two teenage children. One of them is a 13-year-old boy named Murad. Murad goes to the sixth class of secondary school. Another is an 11-year-old boy, and he goes to secondary school, too. His name is Nihad and he is in the fifth class. Sanan’s wife, Narmin, is a housewife who does not work in a business for income. The members of Sanan’a family are IDP (internally displaced persons) from Cabrayil city who now live in the Absheron region.

It’s noted that Sanan is a parquet master, and now he needs a loan of 1,400 AZN ( Azerbaijan New Manat). With this loan he wants to buy materials needed in his work. He is thankful to Komak and Kiva for their help. In the future he wants to have an employee to help him in his work.

loans.use: to buy materials needed in his work.

loans.name: Murad

texts.en:
Murad is 40 years old. He has been married for 13 years. His family now lives in Boyuk Bahmanli village in the Fuzuli region. For 20 years Murad’s family has been IDP (internally displaced peoples) from their native land Fuzuli city. Murad’s wife is a barber. Murad has a daughter. His daughter is 12 years old and she goes to fifth class.

Murad is a taxi driver. He wants to repair his car. He has been in this business for 15 years. Also, he periodically sells sheep wool. Today he needs 600 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat). Therefore, he applied for a loan from the Komak organization. He is thankful to Komak and Kiva for the loan. In the future he wants to get an air conditioner for his car.

loans.use: to repair his car.

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es: Juan carlos mayor de edad casado con cuatro hijos dos aun bajo su responsabilidad, originario de uno de los municipios de Chinandega ubicado en el occidente del pais, es un microempresario el cual tiene un taller de vulcanizacion asi como también ventas de llantas usadas, en este negocio se ofrece todo tipo de servicios al cliente desde repararar llantas ponchadas hasta de dar mantenimiento a los vehículos, bicicletas, motos entre otros, Juan carlos inicia su negocio desde muy joven el cual aprende en otros talleres y con muchos sacrificios y esfuerzos el logra instalar su propio negocio iniciando con pocas herramientas para darle un buen servicio a sus clientes el arriesga a buscar crédito para mejorar el negocio y asi brindarles un buen servicio a sus clientes, los cuales tiene clientes fijos y eventuales, el objetivo de este credito es para capital de trabajo en la compra de materia prima como: distintos estilos y marcas de llantas para invertir en su negocio al igual que otras herramientas mas. juan Carlos esta muy contento con el apoyo que los inversionistas kivas les ofrece a personas de bajos recursos económicos.
texts.en:
Juan Carlos is a married man and has four children, two of whom are still under his care. He is from one of the municipalities of Chinandega, located in the east of the country. He has a small business: a tire repair shop. He also sells used tires. He offers all kinds of services, from repairing punctured tires to vehicle, bicycle, and motorcycle maintenance.
Juan Carlos started his business at a very young age. He learned in other workshops. Through great sacrifice and hard work he was able to open his own business. He started off with a few tools and provided good customer service. He is now looking for a loan to improve his business and provide a good service to his customers. He has regular and casual clients. His goal for this loan is to use it as working capital in buying basic material such as various styles and brands of tires, and other tools. Juan Carlos is very happy about the support that Kiva lenders provide for people of scarce resources.

loans.use: to buy basic supplies such as tires and tools.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is 34 years old and lives in Montserrado County, home of the country's largest Freeport and the number one commercial county in Liberia. She is married with 3 children ages 2, 6, and 12, and they are in school and live at home. 

She has been selling charcoal since 2001. She started this business with a loan that she took from a club (group saving accounts) and she learned this business from her friends. Her favorite part about her business is the profit she generates every day. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal for her business. In the future she wants to educate her children and build a house. 

She appreciates the supporters of BRAC Liberia and she promises to payback her loan on time.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business

loans.name: Agapi

texts.en:
Agapi lives in Yerevan town with her husband and parents-in-law. She studies at the Economics University after A. Mkhitaryan. 

Together with her lessons, Agapi also provides English classes to school-age children who come to her house.  Thanks to her hard work, Agapi currently has a number of students. 

As the income that Agapi and other members of her family earn is only enough for covering the family's daily costs, Agapi isn't able to pay for her university tuition. She is now asking this loan to be able to pay her tuition and continue her higher education.

Agapi will be very grateful to all her lenders for their support.

loans.use: to pay her university tuition

loans.name: Arpik

texts.en: Arpik is a farmer from the Paruyr Sevak village in the Ararat region. She lives with her husband, two little sons (a six year old and a one year old), and a little daughter (5 years old). With the help of her husband, she is engaged in beekeeping; breeding livestock, including cows, pigs, and hens; and cultivating watermelon, apricots, and grapes. They realize the agricultural products in the local market are their only source of the family income. The barn housing their livestock is currently in poor condition and needs to be renovated. To continue running her agribusiness in a sustainable way, Arpik needs a loan of 2,600 USD to renovate the barn, purchase some forage for the livestock, and pay for harvesting services. She and her family rely on the kind will of the lenders and will be grateful to them for their support.

loans.use: to renovate her barn, purchase some forage for her livestock, and pay for harvesting services.

loans.name: Svetik

texts.en: Svetik is a farmer in Goris city in the Syuniq region. She lives with her husband and works as a cook in the private sector. The salary that she gets is not enough to cover her family's daily expenses. With the help of her husband, Svetik is engaged in breeding livestock, including cows and piglets. Farming is an important source of income for the family. To be able to run it in a sustainable way, Svetik needs a loan of 3,000 USD to purchase five heifers and some forage for her livestock. The loan will help her expand her agribusiness and develop it further. She and her husband rely on the good will of the lenders and will appreciate their support in collecting the needed loan.

loans.use: to purchase five heifers and some forage for her livestock.

loans.name: Kamo

texts.en:
Kamo lives in Masis town with his mother, wife, and son. 

He has been involved in the retail business for already three years. Near the open market of Masis town, Kamo owns a little store where he sells different types of goods (beer, vegetables, and fruits). 

As the only breadwinner of the family, it is very difficult for Kamo to pay the family's daily costs and at the same time cover the costs related to his retail business. Now, because of financial difficulties, Kamo isn't able to purchase new stocks of products to sell to his customers.

Kamo has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. The loan is very important for Kamo, and he hopes for lenders' support.

loans.use: to pay for new stocks of products for his store

loans.name: Vladimir

texts.en:
Vladimir is engaged in farming. Since the last loan, he bought a machine for the production of mixed grains. Last year's events – Vladimir bought a good car, and also he became a father.

The amount of animal feed delivered by feed company recently became much bigger, and at the same time the price went up.  And Vladimir decided to produce animal feed by himself to cut the cost. He hopes to increase his net profit this way.

Vladimir is asking a loan of UAH 30 000 to purchase equipment for producing mixed fodders. He plans to produce animal feed for fattening broilers.

loans.use: to buy equipment for producing mixed fodders

loans.name: Yagub

texts.en:
Yaqub lives with his wife and 2 children. They are living in a hostel that is located in the Absheron region. For 20 years they have been IDP (internally displaced persons) from Dovlatyarli village of Füzuli city. His elder daughter is married. Yaqub’s son, Elchin, is a taxi driver in the same area, and his younger son, İldırım, is taking his first courses at the University.
